column2: 122 yards and 8 touchdowns on only 207 carries. He was simply electric. But does that mean Bucky is going to get the ball 25-30 times a game? Bowles sure didn’t suggest that. In fact

column4: ” Bowles said. “One person really doesn’t get all the carries.” Now Bowles did say Bucky was a “bellcow” but in the next sentence noted he is just part of the Bucs’ running attack. “I thought [Bucky came along] a great deal

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/hes-got-to-stop-thinking-so-much/|“He’s Got To Stop Thinking So Much”|As Bucs coach Todd Bowles met with a gaggle of Tampa Bay pen and mic club members last week at the combine in Indianapolis
column2: when Bowles spoke about rookie outside linebacker Chris Braswell
column3: Joe couldn’t help but think of a pop culture icon from the past. Joe kept thinking of Curly Howard of The Three Stooges and one of his famous lines
column5: but nothing happens.” (Insert sound effect of Curly getting his face slapped.) So why did Bowles’ words make Joe think of Curly? Because Bowles suggested Braswell embodied Curly’s line about thinking; Braswell was doing too much thinking and not enough playing. “He’s got to stop thinking so much
column6: ” Bowles said. “When he thinks he slows down. When he’s sure
column7: he plays with his hair on fire and you can see how fast and physical he is. “When he’s not sure he thinks about it and he’s half-speed. We have to get him past that.” “I’m trying to think
column8: but nothing happens.” Bowles did admit that Braswell was beginning to demonstrate why he was a second-round pick late in the season with his speed and physicality. Well
column9: the numbers don’t bear out that it began clicking for Braswell late
column10: though Joe is looking at production from an edge rusher and not his ability/inability to cover wide receivers. In Braswell’s last nine games
column11: he had two quarterback hits and one sack. That’s about as invisible as an edge rusher can be without putting up Ghost Johnson-like goose eggs. And it’s not like Braswell had a log jam in front of him for playing time. The Bucs were so desperate for production at that position they pulled Bucs sacks king Shaq Barrett out of mothballs. Look
column12: Joe is not going to rag on a rookie edge rusher. It’s very common for them to struggle. Still
column13: Joe would like to see Braswell breathe on a quarterback more than he did last year
column14: especially down the stretch. If it means not thinking is the answer

column1: https://www.joebucsfan.com/2025/03/bucs-continue-to-work-on-a-chris-godwin-deal/|Bucs “Continue To Work” On A Chris Godwin Deal|Before the combine started last week
column2: the Bucs got a two-week extension to get a deal done with wide receiver Chris Godwin that pushed the deadline to sign him and avoid a massive cap hit to March 12. That just so happens to be the very same day that the free agency dinner bell sounds. So the reporting yesterday by Dan Graziano of BSPN adds up — the Bucs “continue to work” to get Godwin signed
column3: the long-time BSPN insider typed. … It’s unclear at this point whether they can reach an agreement
column4: but the hallmark of Tampa Bay’s 2024 free agency was its ability to retain its own
column5: including Mike Evans and Baker Mayfield — so they’re optimistic about their chances of reaching a deal with Godwin. Yes
column6: the Bucs are optimistic. What is less known is how optimistic the Bucs are that they won’t be signing damaged goods. Joe did not like the vibe Joe was getting from Bucs AC/DC-loving general manager Jason Licht and Todd Bowles last week in Indianapolis. Both raved about Godwin the person and the player. Both were eager to have Godwin back. Both seemed hesitant and/or depressed when discussing his surgically-repaired ankle. And that’s the issue right there. Do the Bucs sign Godwin to
column8: an $18 million annual deal without fully knowing if or how well he can run routes and evade defenders? Can the Bucs sign Godwin to an incentive-laden contract that provides the Bucs a safety net? Would Godwin’s camp even agree to such a contract? What other teams are out there that are so desperate for a wide receiver they’d risk paying Godwin big money even if he’s damaged goods? Lot of things for the Bucs to sort through in the next nine days. In seven days
